instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Hey guys working on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, did some troubleshooting and came to the conclusion that i'm not getting 3v3 s0. No short to ground but after checking further i see that it comes from <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, it is 0v not enabling <CHIP>U8180</CHIP> to open. I have 3v3 s5 on pin 5 as always i get confused with this <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> output signals is this bad <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> or something else is stopping it from outputting this signal.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> voltage present?
if not this would suggest another problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> is not present then I ver much doubt S4 will be there.....

<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>? Are you using a REAL 85W charger? Green/orange light present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27906"]If <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> is not present then I ver much doubt S4 will be there.....

<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>? Are you using a REAL 85W charger? Green/orange light present? [/QUOTE]


<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4,   <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.404 Real 85w charger green and orange light present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27936"]Any history on this board? [/QUOTE]

Only history i know is that someone else tried to work on the board, but when it got into my hands it had a short on ppbus, I remember you told me that the cpu usually dies. The short was on <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> i did not think the short would go away so i replaced the chip and it did ppbus is stable but those signals are still missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Uhm, why are we bothering with this, CPU is dead. Also how can <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> cause a short on PPBUS? Only <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> could have done that and killed the CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 27960"]Uhm, why are we bothering with this, CPU is dead. Also how can <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> cause a short on PPBUS? Only <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> could have done that and killed the CPU.[/QUOTE]
Say no more when I removed the <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> the short was gone but I get it it's a dead dog because it got zapped  just thought it had a chance to survive when pbus came back. Mark as solved I waste no more time.
